Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation2: The acquaintance passes another person in a quiet hallway.
Story: It was Sunday afternoon, and I remembered I hadn’t texted my parents all week. Guilt pricked at me as I typed a quick message, asking how they were and promising to call soon. I knew they worried if I went silent, and I wanted to reassure them, even if it was just a few words. As I hit send, I walked down the nearly empty hallway of my apartment building. Just then, I spotted Mark, an acquaintance from down the hall, coming toward me. He looked up, expecting a smile or a friendly greeting. My phone buzzed in my hand—my mom’s reply, probably wanting to chat. I felt torn. If I stopped to text my parents, I’d seem rude to Mark, but if I focused on being friendly to Mark, I’d delay the communication my parents expected. My mind raced, caught between the warmth of home and the social ease of the hallway, unsure which role to honor in that moment.
